as a wedding photographer i became very skilled at selling a vision demonstrating my competence quickly and

follow the thread develop a clear picture in your mind understand their vision their priorities

so as i mentioned i became began my time with my clients by asking questions this

sometimes my questions help them develop one sometimes my questions expose
differences of opinions between the stakeholders this is all great it's a
healthy and productive conversation and it's good to have it at the beginning
then both as a wedding photographer and on a software project only after i have
that clear vision of how they want their experience to go only then do i start showing them my work and i choose to
show them work that is relevant to their goals now i want to make two main points here
first whenever possible show don't tell actions speak and so much
louder than words this is your chance to demonstrate that you were listening and that you understand their wants and
their needs the second point is don't always show the latest and greatest or the project
that you consider to be your personal best consider their needs i'm not going to show photographs of a 300 person
luxury hotel wedding to a couple who's going to have a 15-person ceremony in
their backyard likewise i wouldn't want to present a whole event-driven architecture solution
to a client who only has messaging between two microservices so the challenge for us is to ask good
questions what do you use today what do you like about what you use
today what don't you like about what you use today what's holding you back what what takes
too long what has too many clicks too many steps is too complicated did we get the defaults right it's amazing how
often we assume this i had a student of mine once who told me a story he said that he was sitting with one of his
customers was showing off some new feature and the very first thing the customer did was undo all the defaults
that they had set and so my students said well hang on a sec aren't those the right defaults and the customer said oh heck no no we
always undo all that and my student was obviously very upset about we're not upset but he's like oh
my gosh i'm so sorry and so he ran back to his desk he changed the configuration pushed it came back said refresh
and now the defaults were right and the customer's like oh my god you you listen to me and this is what we want this is what we
need you know this is an opportunity for you to show your expertise you know again
show don't tell or to put it another way tell me you're a developer without telling me you're a developer
now everyone in this room has deep technical understanding right we live and breathe this stuff it's what we love
to do you've got all this information and it's so tempting for us to just want to like throw it all in your face be
like here's all this cool stuff i know and sometimes it's our way of trying to establish that credibility i'm really smart i know what i'm talking about
here's some buzzwords take a deep breath relax you've got plenty of time to get
into it you will first step is for us to learn we only learn by listening
what we're trying to get to is this point where they come to you and are asking your opinion we want to be
trusted advisors to our customers that was always my goal as an architect was
to get to that stage with my clients where they looked at me as a trusted advisor right and then it's on us to then
strategically deploy that when it is relevant to our customers
so i generally didn't talk to new clients about the technical details of photographer of photography and believe
me there's mountains of technical details instead i let my work speak for itself but there are times when i did
talk tech and i would educate as a part of selling if a couple's wedding had a component that was technically difficult
to photograph like a ceremony in a particularly small dark room with no natural light not unlike where we are
now i would talk about that difficulty i would teach them what made it hard and i
would tell them what i would do to solve the problem then i would show results i would show
examples of photographs using that methodology besides building trust educating about relevant technical
details has other benefits first in software if and when the client does some
research and solutioning without your direct guidance never happens this will empower them to
avoid pitfalls and avoid taking the project off track or if you're still in the selling phase
now the client will ask other potential vendors what they would do to solve this problem and ask to see examples in
wedding photography i would go so far as to directly suggest that my couples do
this that they asked to see examples of other photographers work that solve this problem
wedding foot couples generally interview three three photographers before hiring one
for their big day so statistically i should have booked at about 33 percent but i booked at 90
i had the success because i made my clients feel heard and understood i demonstrated my knowledge by asking
informed questions and by showing work that is relevant to their experience
our job ultimately is to educate you know i think that's basically my job i get to try to teach people these things
and so it's up to us to teach our customers what they need to know about our technologies
it's easy to look insecure in some of these situations and it's really really important that we be able to take our

so they can make that connection between what this does for them which means we've got to avoid the jargon and the

lot of them in this industry you know we work with the spring folks pretty closely and i always have to remind
myself that to most of the people on this planet spring is a season it is not in fact a java framework so it is
important for us to be able to take our technical knowledge and put it into terms that they understand we have to
understand their domains i spent a long time working with investments folks and i had to have them explain like tranches
to me more times than i care to admit and it just never quite clicked in for me and so we have to remember that our
customers have this jargon as well and i think frankly a glossary is one of the most powerful artifacts you can have on
a project to make sure we're all on the same page about what this stuff means be very very careful with buzzwords you
know we've all played buzzword bingo i actually found out about halfway through my last semester that my students had
made a buzzword bingo card for me which i think means i need new stories because clearly i say a lot of the same
stuff over and over again unsurprisingly coffee was a major component of their buzzword bingo cards for me
our customers don't know these things they shouldn't know these things one of the most depressing conversations i ever

whistles and of course my reaction was why is someone on the business side even
aware there is such a thing as wisdos this is not something they should be dealing with that's our job
so how do we inform them of these things in a way that's interesting and relatable to them
and their domains and their world again don't make assumptions this gets
us in trouble all the time what we can do is show them similar things that we've worked on in the past
or similar things that exist in the universe there's a pretty good chance that you've not encountered this exact
scenario but we can probably get close and so this is also an opportunity for you to validate to your customer i was

what things you don't like to do what's your diet like if they're not asking those kinds of questions that's not
someone you want to work with it's a chance for us to play trust but verify and challenge your own

always be closing mindset now obviously we're selling to a different group of consumers
than pure sales people we're selling our designs to our peers we think this is the right way to do
this we're selling this to our managers to say hey please give me a promotion or a raise or a bonus and we're obviously
selling this to our customers that we know what we're doing and we actually have your best interest in mind
the goal here is to win that trust with those customers now one of the big challenges we face is
we don't always get direct access to our end users this has been a perennial issue in
software i was actually talking with our colleague cote this morning about this that there's this gap between the people
who pay for software and the people who use the software this is part of the reason why software tends to be
less than good not as good as it could be now beginning in my career it was very stark it was oh no we don't want you
developer people talking to the customers you know so if you've ever seen office space you know i take the requirements
from the fax machine and i bring them to the developers because i have people skills and i was always kind of offended
by that like why not i mean i get along with people pretty well i mean maybe my wife would disagree but you know i think
i'm okay at this people thing it gives us a chance to collect information that's what we're striving
to do here it's not as hard as it seems we just have to get the ball rolling and give people an opportunity to talk
most people love to talk if we give them the chance so ask good questions ask follow-up
questions keep giving them these opportunities to give you more information they give you
an answer ask more questions about that answer and see where that thread goes rinse and repeat it's amazing what
they'll tell you if you give them the opportunity okay so we've built trust by asking
great questions and by showing them work that's relevant to their wedding or software experience that they want to
have what's next the next way you can build trust is with a hands-on experience for example my wedding
packages included a free engagement session this had two major benefits first i
built trust by having them experience my process first hand and with stellar results
and when i first started in tech i was surprised to see a similar thing happens i used to be on a pre-sales team where
we would build proof of concepts with new or potential software clients this took the form of implementing the
minimal viable software solution and a neutral cloud environment and this way we could demonstrate
expertise show off the product and give the customer a hands-on experience before doing the work of getting it into
production second with both wedding photography and with software i identified problems
early before they became problems in photography these were often problems of
self-perception for example discovering that a groom is sensitive about his forehead looking too large
but i don't judge people or how they look i'm not judging how he looks to me he's just a normal guy with a normal
forehead so i don't see it without him telling me and he wouldn't have told me if we didn't go through this engagement
session process so this taste test experience likely saved me from having him decide he
didn't like all of his wedding day photographs software is the same by making a
relevant demo on time and with stellar results and with excellent communication
we're able to build a lot of trust and just like with wedding photography in many cases we're able to identify
problems before they become problems for the record i can relate to that thing my kid takes great joy in pointing
out that i had more hair when i was younger and i keep reminding him that this is your future too
he doesn't he doesn't like that so this also again gives us a chance to demonstrate that we've listened it's
also a chance for us to show that we're experts in this field now this happens a lot you may be underestimated
that comes with the territory don't take that personally you will prove yourself
over time imagine you're the subject in this photo your wedding photographer is asking you

best guess is i've been to over 500 weddings and to be completely honest i

wedding couples never had a clue that i felt that way i never lost sight of the

i was very truly happy for them and i mirrored their excitement in other words put yourself in their

she was an expert on the existing system as soon as i took the existing system

now this is not a problem i can solve as a software engineer there is no software solution to this problem

what we say 38 comes from tone how we say it 55 comes from body language
so absolutely tone matters if you want your customers to be excited you have to

work is bringing in new toys and trying to figure that out so what's holding you back what's
preventing you from doing that you know you have to be willing to jump in i mean what is the worst thing that can
possibly happen it'll be okay we'll get you a towel and the wedding photography cadence so
far we've knocked their socks off in the interview given them a taste of what we can do with the engagement session and
then similar similarly with the software project we've asked great questions and demonstrated that we were listening by
building out the proof of concept in each case we built a good amount of trust
the next step is to clearly communicate our expectations about how the actual project should go whether that is a
wedding day or whether it's creating a software solution that will eventually make it to production
the first major goal of planning is to set expectations this will likely be another opportunity to educate your
clients for example with weddings i'd request the wedding day schedule but i
tie this request in with written advice about the amount of time i need to get
everything documented optimally if your client is working with a technology that's unfamiliar to them
they may appreciate some scaffolding rather than starting their solution from scratch with wedding day
photography i would ask for a list of formal portraits to help i would provide
an example list for them to work from as far as as well as some advice about how to make the process efficient
then their job is simply to modify my example list to reflect the names and relationships of their loved ones this
has the added benefit of me receiving that information in exactly the format that makes the most sense to me
finally i would ask the wedding couple for a cast of characters basically an explanation of who's in their family are
their parents still together will their siblings be in attendance are the grandparents still around that sort of
thing just like in software it helps me to understand why the portraits are what they are not just what
like they could say they won a wedding day portrait of bob alice trent and mallory i have no idea who those people
are but if they say they want a wedding day portrait of the groom and his siblings that makes a lot more sense but
really in the end i want both the what and the why the clearer my mental
picture the better having my wedding couples provide these three things the wedding day schedule
the cast of characters and the list of formal portraits has an additional benefit these documents together define
what success looks like for the wedding day couple with weddings and with software projects
it is important to define success not only to ensure that everyone has the same goals but also so that you have a
source of truth you can refer to if things go awry does that ever happen
never not with either the last point i want to make everyone's always on time and do exactly what they
say the last point i want to make here is that i would gather all of this information well before the wedding day
that way i could make sure i was set up for success is there enough time in the schedule to document all that the
committed couples say isn't important to them if not i need to have a conversation with them and either
procure more time or cut back on the list of portraits that they're asking for it is easy to have that conversation in
advance it's much harder if you're asking them to make compromises on the wedding day itself
okay now we feel totally set up for success but how are we meant to find those non-obvious expectations like
assumptions that they're making or details they simply forgot to mention with weddings i came up with a solution
for this it took me a shamefully long time to figure this out okay this is what i did
i would directly ask no one could have predicted this i would ask is there anything you would
like me to photograph that wouldn't be immediately obvious to me for example are you carrying your grandfather's
pocket watch are your mom and her siblings together for the first time in 10 years did you choose your venue
because the field of wildflowers next door reminds you of your aunt who recently passed
away these are important things that as a wedding photographer knew the situation i never could have guessed
so now you have the lay of the land it's time to actually apply that knowledge so do you know what's important to your
customers do you know what matters most for them do you know who all your stakeholders
are this is another place we get in trouble all the time not truly identifying our stakeholders you know you may have heard something but but is
that actually from the stakeholder or someone making an assumption about what the stakeholder wants you know so we need to understand who
they are now some of them are incredibly obvious you know in our wedding metaphor the parents of the bride turn out to be
important players in today's drama there are others that's a little subtler it's harder to
maybe peel that out you know turns out maybe grandma is actually really important because well she's paying for
the whole thing others might not even be visible unless you look closely and you realize oh the
dog must be important because they put it in the flowers now some people would refer to these as
level two players so they're not directly involved but they can absolutely hurt or harm your project and
their presence is felt so if you've ever been in a meeting and someone utters some variation of oh the vp will never
go for that okay should we get her in the room then and ask her directly
you know does the mere idea of someone get in the way are we worried about someone stepping on us in some way shape
or form you can't negotiate with a ghost you can't negotiate with someone who's not in the room
this means we have to have to actively manage these stakeholders and we also have to understand that not all
stakeholders are created equally so in my previous company we actually talked about this in terms of power and
interest and so we looked at it in terms of low power high power low interest high interest we use this matrix to help us
understand where as architects should we be spending our time it should be obvious that low power low
interest people are not your major focus that is not where you're going to spend all of your time
high power high interest yes we will get you whatever you want even if that's an extra cover on your tps report so we'll
get you whatever you need so we have to understand this matrix now obviously
